{{See also|Climate change in New Zealand|Climate of New Zealand}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} [[File:NZU-NZ-emission-unit-720by540.svg|thumb|top|400px|New Zealand Unit Prices 2010 to 2016]] The '''New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme''' (NZ ETS) is a partial-coverage all-free allocation uncapped highly internationally linked [[emissions trading scheme]]. The NZ ETS was first legislated in the [[Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2008]] in September 2008 under the [[Fifth Labour Government of New Zealand]]<ref name="parker08">{{cite press release |url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/historic+climate+change+legislation+passes |title=Historic climate change legislation passes |last=Parker |first=David |authorlink=David Parker (New Zealand politician) |date=10 September 2008 |publisher=New Zealand Government |accessdate=10 September 2008}}</ref><ref name="ccret">{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2008/0085/latest/DLM1130932.html |title=Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2008 No 85 |publisher=Parliamentary Counsel Office |work=legislation.govt.nz |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=25 January 2010 }}</ref> and then amended in November 2009<ref name="smith251109">{{cite press release|url=http://beehive.govt.nz/release/balanced+new+law+important+step+climate+change |title=Balanced new law important step on climate change |publisher= New Zealand Government |author=Hon Nick Smith |authorlink=Nick Smith (New Zealand politician) |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=14 June 2010 }}</ref> and in November 2012<ref name='groser12'>{{cite press release |url= http://beehive.govt.nz/release/ets-amendment-bill-passes-third-reading |title= ETS Amendment Bill passes third reading |publisher= New Zealand Government |date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=12 November 2012}}</ref> by the [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand]].
The NZ ETS covers forestry (a net sink), energy (42% of total 2012 emissions), industry (7% of total 2012 emissions) and waste (5% of total 2012 emissions) but not pastoral agriculture (46% of 2012 total emissions).<ref name='snapshot'>{{cite web |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/sites/default/files/media/Climate%20Change/ghg-inventory-2014-snapshot.pdf |title= New Zealand's Greenhouse Gas Inventory 1990–2012 Snapshot |author= MfE |work= Ministry for the Environment |date= April 2014 |accessdate= 16 February 2015}}</ref> Participants in the NZ ETS must surrender one emission unit (either an international 'Kyoto' unit or a New Zealand-issued unit) for every two tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions reported or they may choose to buy NZ units from the government at a fixed price of NZ$25.<ref name="MfESept09"/>
Individual sectors of the economy have different entry dates when their obligations to report emissions and surrender emission units take effect. Forestry, which contributed net removals of 17.5 [[Megatonnes#Derived units|Mts]] of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|CO<sub>2</sub>e]] in 2010 (19% of NZ's 2008 emissions,<ref name="mfe4-10">{{Cite web |author=MfE |date= April 2010 |title= New Zealand's Greenhouse Gas Inventory 1990–2008 |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/greenhouse-gas-inventory-2010/index.html |work = ME 1009 |publisher= Ministry for the Environment |accessdate=22 May 2010 |issn= 1179-223X}}</ref>) entered the NZ ETS on 1 January 2008.<ref name="forest">{{cite web | title =How will the changes impact on forestry? |author=MfE | work = Questions and answers about amendments to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) | publisher = Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government (www.climatechange.govt.nz) | date = 14 January 2010 | url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/questions-and-answers-amendment-act.html#forestry |accessdate=16 May 2010 }}</ref> The stationary energy, industrial processes and liquid fossil fuel sectors entered the NZ ETS on 1 July 2010. The waste sector (landfill operators) entered on 1 January 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/participating/waste/ |title=Waste - New Zealand Climate change information |publisher=Ministry for the Environment |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=26 July 2011 }}</ref> From November 2009, methane and nitrous oxide emissions from pastoral agriculture were scheduled to be included in the NZ ETS from 1 January 2015.<ref name="MfESept09">{{Cite web | author=MfE | title = Summary of the proposed changes to the NZ ETS | work = Emissions trading bulletin No 11 | publisher = Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government | date = September 2009 | url = http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-trading-bulletin-11/index.html#summary | accessdate =15 May 2010}}</ref> However, agriculture was indefinitely excluded from the NZ ETS in 2013.<ref name="2012 amend info">{{cite web|title=Legislative changes to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS)|url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/ets-amendments/|work=climatechange.govt.nz|publisher=Ministry for the Environment|year=2013|accessdate=17 April 2013}}</ref>
The NZ ETS is highly linked to international carbon markets as it allows the importing of most of the [[Kyoto Protocol]] emission units. It also creates a specific domestic unit; the 'New Zealand Unit' (NZU), which will be issued by free allocation to emitters, with no auctions intended in the short term.<ref name='unit'>{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/about/emission-units.html |title=New Zealand Units (NZUs) |work=Climate change information New Zealand |publisher=Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government (www.climatechange.govt.nz) |date=18 June 2010 |accessdate=13 August 2010 |quote=In the short term, the Government is unlikely to sell emission units because the Kyoto units allocated to New Zealand will be needed to support New Zealand’s international obligations, as well as allocation to eligible sectors under the emissions trading scheme.}}</ref> Free allocation of NZUs will vary by sector. The commercial fishery sector (who are not participants) will receive a free allocation of units on a historic basis.<ref name="MfESept09"/> Owners of pre-1990 forests will receive a fixed free allocation of units.<ref name="forest"/> Free allocation to emissions-intensive industry,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/node/17690 |title=Who will get a free allocation of emission units? |work=Questions and answers about the emissions trading scheme |publisher=Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government |accessdate= 15 May 2010 |date= 14 January 2010 }}</ref><ref name='ag'>{{cite web |author=MfE |url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-trading-bulletin-11/index.html#agriculture |title=Agriculture |work=Summary of the proposed changes to the NZ ETS - Emissions Trading Bulletin 11 |publisher=Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government |accessdate=16 May 2010 |date=September 2009 }}</ref> will be provided on an output-intensity basis. For this sector, there is no set limit on the number of units that may be allocated.<ref name="bull12">{{cite web | author=MfE | title = Industrial allocation update | work = Emissions trading bulletin No 12, INFO 441 | publisher = Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government | date = September 2009 | url = http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-trading-bulletin-12/index.html | accessdate =8 August 2010 | quote=The Bill changes the allocation provisions of the existing CCRA from allocating a fixed pool of emissions to an uncapped approach to allocation. There is no longer an explicit limit on the number of New Zealand units (NZUs) that can be allocated to the industrial sector. }}</ref> The number of units allocated to eligible emitters will be based on the average emissions per unit of output within a defined 'activity'.<ref name="cap">{{cite web |author=MfE |title = How will free allocation of emission units to the industrial sector work now? |work = Questions and answers about amendments to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) |publisher = Ministry for the Environment, NZ Government |date = 14 January 2010 |url = http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/building/policy-and-legislation/faq-amendment-act.html |accessdate = 16 May 2010}}</ref> Bertram and Terry (2010, p 16) state that as the NZ ETS does not 'cap' emissions, the NZ ETS is not a cap and trade scheme as understood in the economics literature.<ref name="cchallenge">{{cite book |last = Bertram | first = Geoff |last2 = Terry |first2 = Simon |title = The Carbon Challenge: New Zealand’s Emissions Trading Scheme |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xUa6Ohd6SaIC |quote=The New Zealand ETS does not fit this model because there is no cap and therefore no certainty as to the volume of emissions with which the national economy must operate |publisher = Bridget Williams Books, Wellington |year = 2010 |isbn = 978-1-877242-46-5 }}</ref>
Some stakeholders have criticized the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme for its generous free allocations of emission units and the lack of a carbon price signal (the [[Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment]]),<ref name="pce1">{{cite press release |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0910/S00231.htm |title=New bill ‘weakens ETS’ says Environment Commissioner|publisher=Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment |date=15 October 2009 |accessdate=15 October 2009 |quote=The allocation of free carbon credits to industrial processes is extremely generous and removes the carbon price signal where New Zealand needs one the most}}</ref> and for being ineffective in reducing emissions ([[Greenpeace Aotearoa New Zealand]]).<ref name="greenpeace">{{cite press release |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0909/S00153.htm |title=Revised ETS an insult to New Zealanders |date=14 September 2009 |publisher=Greenpeace New Zealand |accessdate=12 October 2009 |quote=We now have on the table a pathetic ETS which won’t actually do anything to reduce emissions }}</ref>
The NZ ETS was reviewed in late 2011 by an independent panel, which reported to the public in September 2011.<ref name="ETSreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/ets-review-2011/statement-for-consultation.html |title=Issues statement for public consultation |work=NZ ETS Review 2011 |publisher=Ministry for the Environment |date=21 April 2011 |accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref> In response, the NZ ETS was amended in November 2012.<ref name='groser12'/>
==Economics== {{See also|economics of climate change mitigation}}
===Pricing the externality=== An emissions trading scheme for greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) works by establishing [[Property rights (economics)|property rights]] for the [[atmosphere]].<ref name=goldemberg>{{cite book |year=1996 |contribution=Introduction: scope of the assessment. |title=Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor=J.P. Bruce ''et al'' |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |isbn=978-0-521-56854-8 |doi=10.2277/0521568544|author=Goldemberg, J. |displayauthors=etal |page=29}}</ref> The atmosphere is a global [[public good]], and GHG emissions are an international [[externality]] (p. 21). The emissions from all sources of GHGs contribute to the overall stock of GHGs in the atmosphere. In the '''cap-and-trade''' variant of emissions trading, a limit on access to a resource ('''the cap''') is defined and then allocated among users in the form of permits. Compliance is established by comparing actual emissions with permits surrendered including any permits '''traded''' within the '''cap'''.<ref name="Tietenberg03">{{cite journal |first=Tom |last=Tietenberg |title=The Tradable-Permits Approach to Protecting the Commons: Lessons for Climate Change |url= http://oxrep.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/19/3/400?ijkey=324rjCyD25Jfk&keytype=ref |journal= Oxford Review of Economic Policy |volume= 19 |issue=3 |pages=400–419 |year=2003 |accessdate= |doi=10.1093/oxrep/19.3.400}}</ref> The environmental integrity of emissions trading is depends on the setting of the cap, not the decision to allow trading.<ref name='Driesenelaw40'>{{cite journal |title=Capping Carbon |url=http://www.elawreview.org/elaw/401/capping_carbon.html |author=David M. Driesen |journal=Environmental Law |volume= 40 |issue= 1 |pages= 1–55 |quote=Setting the cap properly matters more to environmental protection than the decision to allow, or not allow, trades}}</ref>
===Efficiency and equity=== For the purposes of analysis, it is possible to separate [[economic efficiency|efficiency]] (achieving a given objective at lowest cost) and [[equity (economics)|equity]] (fairness).<ref>Goldemberg ''et al.''., 1996, p. 29</ref> Economists generally agree that to regulate emissions efficiently, all polluters need to face the full costs of their actions (that is, the full [[margin (economics)|marginal]] [[social cost]]s of their actions).<ref>Goldemburg et al, 1996, pp. 29, 37</ref> Regulation of emissions that is applied only to one economic sector or region drastically reduces the efficiency of efforts to reduce global emissions.<ref>Goldemburg et al, 1996, p. 30</ref> There is, however, no scientific consensus over how to share the costs and benefits of reducing future climate change ([[climate change mitigation|mitigation]] of climate change), or the costs and benefits of [[climate change adaptation|adapting]] to any future climate change (see also [[economics of global warming#Paying for an international public good|economics of global warming]]).
===Carbon leakage=== A domestic ETS can only regulate the emissions of the country having the trading scheme. In this case, GHG emissions can "leak" ([[carbon leakage]]) to another region or sector with less regulation (p. 21). Leakages may be positive, where they reduce the effectiveness of domestic emission abatement efforts. Leakages may also be negative, and increase the effectiveness of domestic abatement efforts (negative leakages are sometimes called spillover) (IPCC, 2007).<ref>{{cite book |year= 2007 |author= IPCC |contribution= Glossary A-D |url= http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/annex1sglossary-a-d.html |title=Annex I: Glossary |series= Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor= B. Metz|publisher= Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |accessdate=25 August 2010|display-editors=etal}}</ref> For example, a [[carbon tax]] applied only to developed countries might lead to a positive leakage to developing countries (Goldemberg ''et al.'', 1996, pp. 27–28). However, a negative leakage might also occur due to technological developments driven by domestic regulation of GHGs.<ref>{{cite book |year= 2007 |contribution= Executive Summary |title= Mitigation from a cross-sectoral perspective |series= Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor= B. Metz ''et al'' |publisher= Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |url= http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch11s11-es.html |isbn= |doi= |author= Barker, T. |displayauthors= etal }}</ref> This can help to reduce emissions even in less regulated regions.
===Competitiveness risks=== One way of addressing carbon leakage is to give sectors vulnerable to international competition free emission permits (Carbon Trust, 2009).<ref>{{cite book |date=March 2009 |author=Carbon Trust |contribution=Memorandum submitted by The Carbon Trust (ET19) |series=Minutes of Evidence, Tuesday 21 April 2009. |title=The role of carbon markets in preventing dangerous climate change |publisher=UK Parliament House of Commons Environmental Audit Select Committee. The fourth report of the 2009-10 session |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmenvaud/290/9042105.htm |accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> This acts as a [[subsidy]] for the sector in question. Free allocation of permits was opposed by the [[Garnaut Climate Change Review]] as it considered there were no circumstances that justify it and that governments could deal with market failure or claims for compensation more transparently with the revenue from full auctioning of permits.<ref name='garnaut'/> The economically efficient option would, however, be border adjustments (Neuhoff, 2009;<ref>{{cite book |date=22 February 2009 |author=Neuhoff, K. |contribution= Memorandum submitted by Karsten Neuhoff, Assistant Director, Electric Policy Research Group, University of Cambridge |series=Written evidence |title=The role of carbon markets in preventing dangerous climate change |publisher= UK Parliament House of Commons Environmental Audit Select Committee. The fourth report of the 2009-10 session |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmenvaud/290/290we22.htm |accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref> Newbery, 2009).<ref>{{cite book |date=26 February 2009 |author=Newbery, D. |contribution= Memorandum submitted by David Newbery, Research Director, Electric Policy Research Group, University of Cambridge |series= Written evidence |title=The role of carbon markets in preventing dangerous climate change |publisher=UK Parliament House of Commons Environmental Audit Select Committee. The fourth report of the 2009-10 session |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmenvaud/290/290we33.htm |accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> Border adjustments work by setting a tariff on imported goods from less regulated countries. A problem with border adjustments is that they might be used as a disguise for trade [[protectionism]].<ref>{{cite journal |date=3 August 2009 |title=Climate Policy and Industrial Competitiveness: Ten Insights from Europe on the EU Emissions Trading System |journal=Climate Strategies |accessdate=14 April 2010 |url=http://www.climatestrategies.org/our-reports/category/17/204.html|author=Grubb, M. |displayauthors=etal |page =5}}</ref> Some types of border adjustment may also not prevent emissions leakage.
===Issuing the permits: 'grandfathering' versus auctions=== Tradable emissions permits can be issued to firms within an ETS by two main ways: by free allocation of permits to existing emitters or by auction.<ref>{{citation |year=2007 |contribution=Section 13.2.1.3 Tradable permits |title=Chapter 13: Policies, instruments, and co-operative arrangements |series= Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editor=B. Metz ''et al'' |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch13s13-2-1-3.html |accessdate=10 July 2010 |author=Gupta, S. |displayauthors=etal }}</ref> Allocating permits based on past emissions is called "grandfathering" (Goldemberg ''et al.''., 1996, p. 38). Grandfathering permits, just like the other option of selling (auctioning) permits, sets a price on emissions. This gives permit-liable polluters an incentive to reduce their emissions. However, grandfathering permits can lead to [[perverse incentive]]s, e.g., a firm that aimed to cut emissions drastically would then be given fewer permits in the future. Allocation may also slow down technological development towards less polluting technologies.<ref>{{cite book |year=1996 |contribution=An Economic Assessment of Policy Instruments for Combating Climate Change. |title=Climate Change 1995: Economic and Social Dimensions of Climate Change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Second Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |editors=J.P. Bruce ''et al.'' |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |isbn=978-0-521-56854-8 |doi=10.2277/0521568544|author=Fisher, B.S. |displayauthors=etal |page=417}}</ref> The [[Garnaut Climate Change Review]] noted that 'grandfathered' permits are not 'free'. As the permits are scarce they have value and the benefit of that value is acquired in full by the emitter. The cost is imposed elsewhere in the economy, typically on consumers who cannot pass on the costs.<ref name='garnaut'>{{cite book |url= http://www.garnautreview.org.au/chp14.htm#14_3 |contribution=Releasing permits into the market |title=The Garnaut Climate Change Review |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-74444-7 |accessdate=28 April 2010 |year=2008 |first=Ross |last=Garnaut }}</ref> However, profit-maximising firms receiving free permits will raise prices to customers because of the new, non-zero cost of emissions.<ref>{{cite book |first=Lawrence H. |last=Goulder |first2=William A. |last2=Pizer |title=The Economics of Climate Change |year=2006 |series=DP 06-06 |publisher=Resources for the Future |url=http://www.rff.org/rff/documents/rff-dp-06-06.pdf }}</ref>
A second method of "grandfathering" is to base allocations on current production of economic goods, rather than historical emissions. Under this method of allocation, government will set a benchmark level of emissions for each good deemed to be sufficiently trade exposed and allocate firms units based on their production of this good. However, allocating permits in proportion to output implicitly subsidises production.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.rff.org/Documents/RFF-DP-04-37.pdf |title=Output-based allocation of emissions permits for mitigating tax and trade interactions |year=2007 |journal=Land Economics |volume=83 |issue=4 |pages=575–599 |last=Fischer |first=C |last2=Fox |first2=A |accessdate=10 August 2010 |quote=However, there often are important trade-offs in terms of efficiency because OBA implicitly subsidizes production, unlike conventional lump-sum allocation mechanisms like grandfathering. }}</ref> Garnaut considers that any method for free permit allocation will have the disadvantages of high complexity, high transaction costs, value-based judgements, and the use of arbitrary emissions baselines.<ref name='garnaut'/>
On the other hand, auctioning permits provides the government with revenues. These revenues could be used to fund low-carbon investment, and also fund cuts in [[distortion (economics)|distortionary]] [[tax]]es. Auctioning permits can therefore be more efficient and equitable than allocating permits (Hepburn, 2006, pp. 236–237).<ref name="Hepburn2006">{{cite journal |year=2006 |title=Regulating by prices, quantities or both: an update and an overview |author=Hepburn, C. |journal=Oxford Review of Economic Policy |volume=22 |issue=2 |doi=10.1093/oxrep/grj014 |url=http://www.economics.ox.ac.uk/members/cameron.hepburn/Hepburn%20(2006,%20Oxrep)%20Regulation%20by%20P%20or%20Q.pdf |pages=226–247 |accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref> Ross Garnaut states that full auctioning will provide greater transparency and accountability and lower implementation and transaction costs as governments retain control over the permit revenue.<ref name='garnaut'/>
Such recycling of revenue from permit auctions could offset a significant proportion of the economy-wide social costs of a cap and trade scheme.<ref name="Stavins2008">{{cite journal |first=Robert N. |last=Stavins |title=Addressing climate change with a comprehensive US cap-and-trade system |journal=Oxford Review of Economic Policy |year=2008 | volume = 24 | issue = 2 24: |pages=298–321 |doi=10.1093/oxrep/grn017 |url= http://oxrep.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/24/2/298 }}</ref> As well as reducing tax distortions, Kerr and Cramton (1998) note that auctions of units are more flexible in distributing costs, they provide more incentives for innovation, and they lessen the political arguments over the allocation of [[economic rents]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kerr |first= Suzi |last2= Cramton |first2= Peter |year= 1998 |title=Tradable Carbon Permit Auctions: How and Why to Auction Not Grandfather |work=Discussion Paper dp-98-34 |publisher=Resources For the Future. |url=http://www.rff.org/documents/RFF-DP-98-34.pdf |quote=An auction is preferred to grandfathering (giving companies permits based on historical output or emissions), because it allows reduced tax distortions, provides more flexibility in distribution of costs, provides greater incentives for innovation, and reduces the need for politically contentious arguments over the allocation of rents.}}</ref>
===Lobbying for free allocation=== According to Hepburn (2006, pp. 238–239),<ref name="Hepburn2006"/> “it should be expected that industry will lobby furiously against any auctioning.” Hepburn ''et al.'' (2006) state that it is an empirical fact that while businesses tend to oppose auctioning of emissions permits, economists almost uniformly recommend auctioning permits.<ref name="cp6.1">{{Cite journal | last = Hepburn | first =Cameron J | last2 = Neuhoff | first2 =Karsten | last3 = Grubb | first3 =Michael | last4 = Matthes | first4 = Felix | last5 = Tse | first5 = Max | title = Auctioning of EU ETS Phase II allowances: why and how? | journal = Climate Policy | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 137–160 | year = 2006 | url = http://www.dspace.cam.ac.uk/bitstream/1810/183630/1/eprg0621.pdf | accessdate = 19 May 2010 | doi=10.3763/cpol.2006.0608}}</ref> Garnaut notes that the complexity of free allocation, and the large amounts of money involved, encourage non-productive [[rent-seeking]] behaviour and lobbying of governments, activities that dissipate economic value.<ref name='garnaut'/>
===New Zealand allocation=== In respect of the 2009 amendments to the NZ ETS, intensity-based allocation was favoured over allocations based on historical emissions by business groups, and representatives of large emitters,<ref name="Fallow" /> by [[Fonterra]]<ref name='hell'>{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Fallow |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/kyoto-protocol/news/article.cfm?c_id=244&objectid=10570390 |title=ETS a step on road to hell: farmers |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=5 May 2009 |accessdate=12 October 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5kSk8Pwem |archivedate=12 October 2009}}</ref> and by [[Federated Farmers]].<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU0911/S00811.htm |title=Fed Farmers takes cold comfort from ETS lobbying |publisher=Federated Farmers |date=26 November 2009 |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> Environmental organisations and opposition political parties opposed intensity based allocations.<ref name="pce1"/><ref name="greenpeace"/><ref name="etsreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/83AC973B-6FDE-4260-846E-E7CCFBD3FE21/113444/DBSCH_SCR_4485_ReviewoftheEmissionsTradingSchemean.pdf |title=Review of the Emissions Trading Scheme and related matters |publisher=Report of the Emissions Trading Scheme Review Committee |date=August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523091627/http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/83AC973B-6FDE-4260-846E-E7CCFBD3FE21/113444/DBSCH_SCR_4485_ReviewoftheEmissionsTradingSchemean.pdf |archivedate=2010-05-23 |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
===Economic modelling=== In June 2009, Nick Smith released an economic modelling report on the NZ ETS by economic consultants [[New Zealand Institute of Economic Research|NZIER]] and Infometrics which had been prepared for the [[Emissions Trading Scheme Review Committee]]. Smith stated that the report supported the Government's intention to modify the NZ ETS.<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0906/S00211.htm |title = Economic analysis supports modified ETS |publisher= New Zealand Government |date= 17 June 2009 |accessdate= 30 April 2012}}</ref> The report ''"Economic modelling of New Zealand climate change policy"''<ref name="ria">{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/documents/economic-modelling-of-new-zealand-climate-change-policy/economic-modelling-of-new-zealand-climate-change-policy.pdf |format=PDF |title= Economic modelling of New Zealand climate change policy |last= Stroombergen |first= A |last2= Schilling |first2= C |last3= Ballingall |first3= J |publisher= NZIER & Infometrics |date= 20 May 2009}}</ref> created static [[computable general equilibrium]] (CGE) models using 2008 emissions projections. The terms of reference set the policy options to look at as the 2008 NZETS vs the least-cost option for meeting the Kyoto liability vs a revenue-neutral tax on carbon equivalents.
The impacts of the various options were estimated as the differences between a carbon tax and a reference ‘business as usual’ scenario assuming New Zealand had not signed the Kyoto Protocol. The variables changed in the model runs were the NZ carbon price ($0, $10, $25 or $100), the world carbon price, the duration (short term to 2012, long term to 2025), the level of free allocation and whether the Government assumed all Kyoto liabilities. The results of each model run was reported as the percent difference from the 'no-Kyoto' ‘business as usual’ scenario in 2012 or 2025.<ref>''Stroombergen et al'' 2009, p 22</ref>
The report noted several limitations of [[computable general equilibrium]] models that should be kept in mind in interpreting the results: CGE models are only an approximation of highly complex real economies, results can only ever be indicative,<ref name="Stroombergen et al 2009, p 16">''Stroombergen et al'' 2009, p 16</ref> and are highly dependent on the structure of the models and the input assumptions and on the assumption that other variables remain constant. Therefore, the "interpretation of CGE results should centre on their direction (up or down) and broad magnitude (small, medium or large), rather than on the precise point estimates that the model produces".<ref name="Stroombergen et al 2009, p 16"/>
The report's bolded conclusion was that a narrow carbon tax or trading scheme was the least cost option in the short-term .<ref>''Stroombergen et al'' 2009, p 40</ref> Predicted reductions in GHG emissions ranged from 0% (Government pays), 0.4% to 2.8% for a $25 carbon price and 3% to 4% for a $50 price.<ref>''Stroombergen et al'' 2009, Table 17, p 38</ref> However, the report noted that there was little difference in costs between the government paying all and the ETS with free allocation, as all the model results indicated small reductions (-0.1% and -0.4%) in Gross National Disposable Income compared to ‘business as usual’.<ref>''Stroombergen et al'' 2009, p 39</ref>
==First version of the emissions trading scheme, 2008== {{main|Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2008}}
===Background=== In 2002, the [[Fifth Labour Government of New Zealand]] adopted the [[Climate Change Response Act 2002]] (the Act) in order for New Zealand to ratify the [[Kyoto Protocol]] and to meet obligations under the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/laws/climate.html |title=Climate Change Response Act |publisher=[[Ministry for the Environment (New Zealand)|Ministry for the Environment]] |accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref>
===Labour's emissions trading scheme=== In 2008, the Labour Government enacted the [[Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2008]] which added the first version of the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme to the Climate Change Response Act 2002.<ref name="ccret"/>
The proposed scheme covered all six greenhouse gases specified in the Kyoto Protocol and was intended to progressively apply to all sectors of the economy including agriculture. 'Participants' (who would account for their emissions) were to be few, and high in the production chain of each sector. Their compliance obligation would have been to surrender one New Zealand unit (NZU) or one internationally tradable Kyoto-compliant unit for each tonne of emissions.
New Zealand units were to be capped in number and were to be allocated to participants either by grandparenting (gifting) or auctioning. Sectors of the economy were to have progressively entered the NZ ETS, with forestry the first from January 2008 and agriculture last in January 2013. Allocation rules varied between sectors. In general, participants who could pass on costs of the ETS, such as fuel companies, would not be allocated free units. Participants such as exporters with products that are priced internationally, would be allocated free units.<ref name='banquet'>{{cite speech |first=David|last=Parker |authorlink=David Parker (New Zealand politician) |url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/speech/new+zealand+emissions+trading+scheme |title=A New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme, Speech at Banquet Hall, Parliament Buildings, Wellington |date=20 September 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609133802/http://www.beehive.govt.nz/speech/new-zealand-emissions-trading-scheme |archivedate=9 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0709/S00350.htm |title= New Zealand emissions trading scheme Questions and answers |date= 20 September 2007 |accessdate= 18 August 2012 |publisher=New Zealand Government }}</ref>
Forest owners with pre-1990 forests were to receive a fixed one-off free allocation of units. Transport (liquid fossil fuels), stationary energy and industrial processes would not receive a free allocation of units. Trade-exposed industries would have received a free allocation of 90% of 2005 emissions annually to 2018. From 2019 to 2029 the free allocation of units would have phased out at the rate of a 1/12 (8.3%) reduction each year. Agriculture would have received a free allocation of 90% of 2005 emissions each year to 2018. From 2019 to 2029 the free allocation would have phased out at the rate of a 1/12 (8.3%) reduction each year. Fishing would have received a free allocation based on 50% of 2005 emissions each year from July 2010 to January 2013.<ref name='fact16' />
The Labour Government subsequently lost the [[New Zealand general election, 2008|2008 New Zealand election]] to the [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand|coalition led by National Party]], who had campaigned on amending the NZ ETS.
==The amendments of 2009==
===History=== In December 2008, the [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand|National-led Government]] set up the [[Emissions Trading Scheme Review Committee]] to review the NZ ETS. The committee provided a report nine months later on 31 August 2009.
In early September 2009, [[Rod Oram]] predicted that the National Government's goals would be; to adopt intensity-based allocation of free carbon credits to export industries; have no cap on greenhouse gas emissions; to have a temporary cap on the price of carbon; to delay bringing in sectors into the NZETS; to delay phasing out free emission units; and, maximum alignment with the Australian [[Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme]]. Oram viewed these changes as significantly weakening the incentives to reduce emissions and to plant carbon forests.<ref name='bar'>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/2837990/Burn-after-reading | title=Burn after reading |first= Rod |last=Oram |work= The Sunday Star Times |date= 6 September 2009 |accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref>
On 14 September 2009, the National Government Minister for Climate Change Issues [[Nick Smith (New Zealand politician)|Nick Smith]] announced that it had reached an agreement with the [[Māori Party]] about revisions to the NZ ETS and that an amending bill would be drafted in order to "make the ETS workable and affordable".<ref name='smith1'>{{cite press release |first=Nick |last=Smith|authorlink=Nick Smith (New Zealand politician) |url=http://beehive.govt.nz/release/revised+ets+balances+nz%E2%80%99s+environment+amp+economy |title=Revised ETS balances NZ's environment & economy |publisher=New Zealand Government Media Release |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=22 September 2009}}</ref>
On 24 September 2009, the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill had its first reading in Parliament and was sent to the Finance and Expenditure Select Committee for public submissions.<ref name='bill'>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/PB/Legislation/Bills/7/a/d/00DBHOH_BILL9597_1-Climate-Change-Response-Moderated-Emissions-Trading.htm |title=Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill |publisher=New Zealand Parliament |date=7 December 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2010}}</ref>
===Submissions to the Finance and Expenditure Committee=== Between 15 October 2009<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/PB/Debates/Debates/0/2/0/49HansD_20091021_00000540-Questions-for-Oral-Answer-Questions-to-Ministers.htm |title=Questions for Oral Answer — Questions to Ministers, Questions to Members |work=Hansard |publisher=New Zealand Parliament |date=20 September 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2010 |author=Craig Foss (Chairperson of the Finance and Expenditure Committee) |quote= The committee began hearing evidence on the bill on Thursday, 15 October 2009, at around 4 p.m.}}</ref> and the date of its final report, 16 November 2009, the Finance and Expenditure Committee received 399 submissions on National's draft bill.<ref name='wfy'>{{cite web |url=http://theyworkforyou.co.nz/bills/climate_change_response_moderated |title=Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill: Government Bill |publisher=TheyWorkForYou.co.nz |accessdate= 30 August 2010}}</ref>
===Absence of a cap on emissions=== In 2007, the [[Ministry for the Environment (New Zealand)|Ministry for the Environment]] released a detailed report "''The Framework for a New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme''" which stated the NZ ETS would not have a binding, absolute limit on the total level of emissions allowed in New Zealand. While the quantity of domestic NZ Units gifted to eligible emitters would be fixed, the quantity of international 'Kyoto-compliant' units that could be imported in to match emissions would not be limited.<ref>{{cite book |author= MfE |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/framework-emissions-trading-scheme-sep07/html/page6a.html |title=The Framework for a New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme - 4 Core Design Features |chapter= 4.8.2 Definition of the cap for the NZ ETS |publisher=Ministry for the Environment |accessdate=18 July 2010 |date=September 2007 |series=Ref. ME810 }}</ref> In consequence, as there is no limit on the volume of international emissions units (CERs and ERUs) that may be imported, there is no cap or limit on the volume of emissions permitted in New Zealand provided that emissions units are imported into the country and surrendered. In that respect, the NZ ETS is unlike most other emissions trading schemes,<ref name='Moyes'>{{cite journal |last=Moyes |first= Toni E. |year= 2008 |title= Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading in New Zealand: Trailblazing Comprehensive Cap and Trade |journal= Ecology Law Quarterly |volume=35 |issue=4 |pages= 911–966. |url = http://www.boalt.org/elq/documents/elq35-4-05-moyes-2009-0309.pdf |quote= Unlike most other ETS, the NZ ETS places no limit on the volume of CERs and ERUs that may be imported (p 936) |accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref>
Ministry for the Environment Fact Sheet 16 stated "There is no cap on the emissions that occur within New Zealand." However, the Ministry for the Environment still regarded the NZ ETS as operating within the cap on emissions established by the Kyoto Protocol for the first commitment period of 2008–2012.<ref name="fact16">{{cite web |author=MfE |url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-factsheets/factsheet-16.html |title=Major design features of the emissions trading scheme |work=Factsheet 16 INFO 318 |publisher=Ministry for the Environment |date=October 2008}}</ref> Moyes (2008) describes this as a "flexible cap" where New Zealand sourced emissions regulated by the NZETS are constrained only by the international market price for GHG emissions.<ref name='Moyes'/>
Nick Smith's press release of September 2009 announced that the method of allocation of NZ units to trade exposed and emissions intensive firms would now be based on average industry production, where the levels of units allocated would vary in proportion to a firm's production.<ref name='smith1'/><ref name='summ'>{{cite book |contribution=Summary of ETS Changes |url= http://beehive.govt.nz/sites/all/files/1_Summary_of_ETS_Changes.pdf |work=Factsheet accompanying Media Release by Nick Smith, Minister for Climate Change Issues |title=Revised ETS balances NZ's environment & economy |author=MfE |date=14 September 2009 |publisher=New Zealand Government |accessdate=22 September 2009}}</ref>
In combination with the unlimited use of internationally sourced Kyoto units, the allocation of New Zealand units to eligible emitters in proportion to their production means that there is no cap on total emissions within New Zealand.<ref name="bull12"/>
There is also no cap on total emissions during the transition period as the Government will supply the market with unlimited New Zealand units at the fixed price of NZ$25 per NZU.
When the NZETS included a proposed free allocation of units to agriculture, there were no eligibility tests. Allocations to agricultural activities were to have been made on an intensity basis. The baseline would have been the sector average emissions per unit of output.
===Allocation of NZ Units to trade-exposed activities=== Under the NZ ETS, all NZ Units are distributed into the market by free allocation (gifting). In 2010, the Ministry for the Environment stated that there was no intention in the short term to auction any NZ Units.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/about/emission-units.html |title=About emission units |work=New Zealand Climate change information |publisher=Ministry for the Environment (www.climatechange.govt.nz) |accessdate=7 August 2010 |date=10 June 2010 |author=MfE}}</ref> 'Emissions-intensive' and 'trade-exposed' (EITE) activities are designated a benchmark level of emissions per unit of production. For example, x amount of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions per tonne of steel. Firms then receive an allocations based on their expected production of the emissions intensive good.
This method of allocation is often referred to as 'intensity based allocation'. Intensity based allocations are allocations that are based on the volume of production of a firm.<ref name="gpvsi">{{cite web | url = http://www.afse.fr/docs/congres2006/docs2006/Demailly.doc | first = Damien | last = Demailly | first2 =Philippe | last2 =Quirion | title = CO2 abatement, competitiveness and leakage in the European cement industry under the EU ETS: Grandfathering vs. output-based allocation | year = 2006 | accessdate = 12 April 2010}}</ref> Allocations are given at the beginning of the period and then balanced at the conclusion to reflect actual output.
The benchmark (or allocative baseline) for free allocation for firms considered emissions-intensive and trade-exposed includes compensation for electricity price increases.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/building/regulatory-updates/eaf-update.html |title= Electricity Allocation Factor Update |last= MfE |publisher = Ministry for the Environment |date= 1 April 2011 |accessdate=21 May 2012}}</ref>
===Fiscal impact of allocation=== From the 2008 election, the policy of the National Party<ref>{{cite web |title=National Party Environment Policy |date=6 September 2008 |url=http://national.org.nz/files/2008/environment%20policy.pdf |accessdate= 22 August 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5rYVRQXqi |archivedate=28 July 2010 |quote=The ETS should be fiscally neutral rather than providing billions of dollars in windfall gains to the government accounts at the expense of businesses and consumers }}</ref> was that the NZ ETS should be fiscally neutral, in the sense of a Government policy where any new taxes or revenues equal any new spending<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/research/economics/alphabetic.cfm?letter=F#fiscalneutrality |title=Economics A-Z |publisher=economist.com |accessdate=18 October 2010 |quote=Fiscal neutrality. When the net effect of taxation and public spending is neutral }}</ref> The policy of a fiscally neutral NZ ETS was confirmed by [[John Key]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.johnkey.co.nz/archives/382-NEWS-National-wont-cut-corners-on-ETS-at-kiwis-expense.html |title=National won't cut corners on ETS at kiwis' expense |author= Rt Hon John Key |publisher= John Key, Prime Minister, National Party |date=18 May 2008 |accessdate=18 October 2010 |quote=It should be fiscally neutral rather than providing billions of dollars in windfall gains to the government accounts at the expense of businesses and consumers }}</ref> [[Bill English]],<ref>{{cite speech |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0808/S00303.htm |first=Bill |last=English: |title=Speech: Climate Change and Business Conference |publisher=New Zealand National Party |work=Scoop.co.nz |accessdate=28 July 2010 |date=20 August 2008 }}</ref> and [[Nick Smith (New Zealand politician)|Nick Smith]] in his speech on the third reading of the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2009.<ref>{{cite speech |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0911/S00385.htm |title= Hon Dr Nick Smith, Minister for Climate Change, Speech, Third Reading, Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill 2009 |publisher=New Zealand Government |date= 25 November 2009 |accessdate= 4 April 2010 |quote=We said we would rejig the scheme to be fiscally neutral so households, farms and businesses would not be funding multi-billion dollar windfall gains to the Government}}</ref>
The cost of free allocation of units to emitters is a highly contentious subject. The Sustainability Council argued that the allocation of units to industry is highly costly to taxpayers.<ref name="terrybert">{{cite web |url=http://www.sustainabilitynz.org/docs/ETSBillToAFutureGenerationNov09.pdf| title=ETS: Bill to a Future Generation | last= Terry | first=Simon|publisher = Sustainability Council| date=12 November 2009}}</ref>
Dr Christina Hood, a climate change and energy policy consultant, submitted to the Finance and Expenditure Select Committee that the use of uncapped intensity based allocation of units will result in a taxpayer subsidy to emitters of about $NZ105 billion up to 2050.<ref name="hood">{{Cite web | title =Submission to the Finance and Expenditure Select Committee on the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill |url= http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/6C882B6B-0972-4EFF-A0F6-EB5D5789FB19/115616/49SCFE_EVI_00DBHOH_BILL9597_1_A14707_DrChristinaHo.pdf | publisher = Dr Christina Hood | date = 14 October 2009 | accessdate = 15 January 2010}}</ref>
Economist Geoff Bertram estimated that at a carbon price of $NZ50 a tonne, the cost to taxpayers of the free allocation of NZ units to emitters will be $NZ99 billion between 2010 and 2091.<ref name="Bertram">{{cite web |first=Geoff |last= Bertram |url= http://ips.ac.nz/events/downloads/2009/Copenhagen%202/Geoff%20Bertram%20-%20How%20Not%20to%20Design%20an%20Emissions%20Trading%20Scheme.pdf |title=How Not to Design an Emissions Trading Scheme |publisher= The Institute of Policy Studies, Victoria University of Wellington |date=13 November 2009 |accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref>
Nick Smith's Cabinet Paper noted that the [[New Zealand Treasury]] had estimated that the long-term costs of intensity-based allocation of units to industry and agriculture would be 'very significant', in the order of $NZ900 million per annum by 2030.<ref name=cabinet>{{cite web |title=Amendments for a Moderated NZ ETS and Second Order Amendments to the Climate Change Response Act |url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/cabinet-papers/egi-09-132.html |work=Cabinet Paper EGI (09) 13/2 |publisher=Office of the Minister for Climate Change Issues |date=9 October 2009 |author= Nick Smith, Minister for Climate Change Issues |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5rsVGMsUb |archivedate=10 August 2010}}</ref>
The Clerk of the House invited Economist Dr Suzi Kerr to give independent specialist advice on the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill. Kerr's advice was that the free allocation of emission units significantly raised the overall cost of the NZ ETS to the economy and transferred it to taxpayers.<ref name="suzikerr2">{{citation |first=Suzi |last=Kerr | title =Comments to select committee, invited independent specialist advice on the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill | url = http://www.motu.org.nz/files/datasets/docs/MEL0473_ETS_submission.pdf | year=2009 | series = Motu Report MEL0473}}</ref>
===Decrease in allocation of units=== The 2009 legislation did not include a specific sunset clause to change the allocation of units to firms that undertake emissions-intensive and trade-exposed activities. The legislation stipulates that allocations must be reviewed no less than once every 5 years by a review panel. In late 2009, Climate Change Minister Nick Smith stated that estimates of fiscal impacts beyond 2020 at the present time are meaningless as there are simply too many unknowns.<ref name="nzh1">{{cite news |last= Fallow |first=Brian |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/carbon-trading/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501831&objectid=10609738 |title=$50b rise in ETS costs 'shows process too rushed'|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=2 February 2010 |date=17 November 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5tgtD1cGX |archivedate=23 October 2010}}</ref>
Although the level of allocation per unit of output for emissions-intensive and trade-exposed industrial activities decreases at 1.3% per year from 2013, as production may increase, allocations may also increase over time.<ref name="pce-sub">{{cite web | last = Wright | first = Jan | title = Submission to the Finance and Expenditure Committee on the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill | url =http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/C2BE71F6-AF44-46C9-B5E0-A215C6EC4D74/115918/49SCFE_EVI_00DBHOH_BILL9597_1_A14959_Parliamentary.pdf | publisher = [[Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment]] | date = 13 October 2009 | accessdate =11 January 2010}}</ref>
===Transitional assistance=== The NZ ETS contains special transitional provisions from 1 July 2010 (when fossil emissions enter the scheme) until 31 December 2012 (transition period). This end date coincides with the end date of the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. Although transitional measures are legislated to end after 2012, the Government has suggested that they will be extended in the event that major trading partners such as the USA and Australia do not implement emissions trading schemes of their own before then.<ref name="delayfulltrading">{{cite web | url = http://www.wbcsd.org/Plugins/DocSearch/details.asp?ObjectId=MzgxNjY | title =NZ says to delay full CO2 trading if no international progress | publisher=New Zealand Business Council for Sustainable Development | date=8 April 2010 | accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref>
During the transition period participants in energy, fossil fuels and industry will only need to surrender one NZU for two tonnes of [[carbon dioxide equivalent]] emissions. Free allocation of units to energy-intensive and trade-exposed activities will also be halved. Secondly, participants may pay a fixed price of NZ$25 instead of buying and surrendering units. This measure means that firms will face a cost of no higher than NZ$12.50 per tonne of emissions. There is a restriction on the sale of units oversea during this transition period, except for forest removal credits.<ref name="MfESept09"/>
===Delayed entry for agricultural emissions=== Agricultural emissions, methane from enteric fermentation and manure management as well as nitrous oxide from animal effluent and fertiliser, were to enter the scheme on 1 January 2015. A 'Questions and Answers' fact sheet released by [[Nick Smith (New Zealand politician)|Nick Smith]] (Minister for Climate Change Issues) stated that the delayed entry was due to the difficulties in measuring and monitoring agricultural emissions and the limited technologies available for reducing emissions in the sector.<ref name="faq"/>
The economic modelling conducted by NZIER and Infometrics stated: {{cquote|If the aim of climate change mitigation policies is to change producers’ behaviour, it is vital to be able to measure emissions in a cost effective manner. If the transaction costs of measuring emissions outweigh the benefits of emissions reduction, the policy may not be net welfare enhancing. Therefore the transaction costs of implementing an all-sectors all-gases ETS need to be evaluated. It may be advisable to exempt sectors such as agriculture where measurement costs are high relative to the benefit that would be gained from that sector’s inclusion. Our modelling suggests that, in the short term, such exemptions do not reduce economy wide welfare.||| ''Stroombergen et al'' 2009<ref name='ria'/>}}
The Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment considered that there was insufficient evidence to justify leaving agriculture out of the NZ ETS until 2015.<ref name="pce-sub"/> A submission from the [[Institute of Policy Studies (New Zealand)]] and The New Zealand Climate Change Research Institute considered that the delayed entry of agriculture into the NZ ETS would reduce long term competitiveness of the New Zealand economy by supporting industry that can not compete in an emissions constrained world.<ref name=IPS-NZCCRI>{{Cite web | last =Bertram | first = Geoff | last2 = Barrett | first2 = Peter | last3 = Boston | first3 = Jonathan | last4 = Chapman | first4 = Ralph | last5 = Lawrence | first5 = Judy | last6 = Manning | first6 = Martin | last7 = Reisinger | first7 = Andy |title=A submission to the Finance and Expenditure Committee on the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Bill |url=http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/4D9F76EC-128A-497A-8DFD-F8267956318E/115992/49SCFE_EVI_00DBHOH_BILL9597_1_A15141_InstituteofPo.pdf |publisher=The Institute of Policy Studies and The New Zealand Climate Change Research Institute, Victoria University of Wellington |date=15 October 2009 |accessdate=13 January 2010}}</ref>
==The Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2009==
===Adoption=== On 25 November 2009, the bill had its second and third readings<ref name="smith251109"/> and it was adopted by 63 votes to 58, with the support of the National Party (58 votes), the Maori Party (4 votes) and United Future (1 vote).<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=NZ Science Media Centre |date=26 November 2009 |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/SC0911/S00059.htm |title= Divisive ETS legislation passed |accessdate= 30 August 2010}}</ref> The Labour Party (43 votes), the Greens (9 votes), ACT (5 votes) and the Progressive Party (1 vote) voted against the third reading.<ref name="wfy"/>
On 7 December 2009, the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2009 received the royal assent.<ref name='bill'/>
===Technical Details=== The Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment Act 2009 established an emissions trading scheme with obligations on emissions from all sectors and all gases.<ref name="smith251109"/><ref name="faq">See [http://beehive.govt.nz/sites/all/files/1_ETS_Questions_Answers.pdf ETS Questions Answers], [http://beehive.govt.nz/sites/all/files/1_Summary_of_ETS_Changes.pdf Summary of ETS Changes], factsheets accompanying New Zealand Government Media Release by Nick Smith, Minister for Climate Change Issues, 'Revised ETS balances NZ's environment & economy' , 14 September 2009. Retrieved 22 September 2009.</ref> From 2015, the technical details can be summarised as: * All emissions from all sources will have obligations. This includes emissions from biological sources such as methane from enteric fermentation and nitrous oxide from animal effluent. * Allocations will be made to firms who undertake activities that are deemed to be both 'trade-exposed' and 'emissions-intensive'. Moderately emissions intensive activities will receive allocations equal to 60% of the industry average for the financial years ending 2007, 2008 and 2009. Highly emissions intensive industries will receive allocations equal to 90% of the industry average for this period. Allocation per unit of output will decrease by 1.3% per year from 2013 (on an exponential basis rather than a summation basis). * As allocations are based on production levels, allocations are not 'capped' at any specific level. * Moderately emissions intensive activities are those that produce more than 800 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions per million dollars of revenue. Highly emissions intensive activities are those that produce more than 1600 tonnes per million dollars of revenue. ** Electricity generators will not receive allocations, however a firm may receive allocation for electricity use if it conducts an 'emissions intensive' and 'trade exposed' activity (EITE). ** Liquid fossil fuel is excluded from allocation in all instances. * Owners of forests planted after 31 December 1989 are able to 'opt-in' to the scheme and receive units for forest sequestration. If these forests are removed from the land the owner must repay these units. * Owners of land that was in forest on 1 January 1990 and remained in forest on 1 January 2008 must surrender emissions units if they wish to deforest land AND change the land use to a use other than forestry. * Agricultural activities will automatically receive a 90% allocation per unit of production, phased out at a rate of 1.3% per year from 2016.

No requirement to report emissions or surrender NZUs || 700,000 NZUs (90% of 2005 emissions) allocated free to fishing quota holders until 1 January 2012. |}
===Units able to be traded=== The NZ ETS created a specific domestic emission unit for use in New Zealand, the New Zealand Unit (NZU). The NZUs are not a [[Kyoto Protocol|Kyoto]] unit in terms of compliance with the Kyoto Protocol, and can only be surrendered or traded within New Zealand. Assigned amount units (AAUs) issued by New Zealand under the Kyoto Protocol can be also used by emitters to meet their surrender obligations, but assigned amount units issued by other Annex B countries may not be used.<ref name='eur'>{{cite web |url= http://www.eur.govt.nz/how-to/guides-hmtl/guide-to-emissions-returns/ |title=Guide to Emissions Returns - SEIP and LFF sectors — New Zealand Emission Unit Register |author= NZEUR |publisher= New Zealand Emissions Unit Register |date= December 2011 |quote=Section 18CB of the Climate Change Response Act 2002 prohibits the use of imported AAUs for compliance purposes. No imported AAUs can be surrendered for NZ ETS compliance purposes as there are no regulations creating an exception to the prohibition. |accessdate=6 September 2012}}</ref>
Participants in the NZ ETS are also able to purchase and surrender international [[Kyoto Protocol|Kyoto]] units such as [[Emission Reduction Unit]]s (ERUs), [[Certified Emission Reduction]]s (CERs) and [[Removal Units]] (RMUs) issued in other countries. Unlike most other emissions trading schemes the NZ ETS has no limit on the volume of international units (CERs and ERUs) that may be imported.<ref name='Moyes'/> Consequently, the NZ ETS is highly linked to the international market for greenhouse gas emission units. This degree of linkage and the lack of a national cap on emissions makes New Zealand a price-taker where control of the price of emissions to firms is relinquished to the international markets.<ref name='Moyes'/>
During the transition phase (July 2010 to December 2012), only the forestry sector will be able to convert the NZUs allocated to them to [[Assigned amount units]] that can be sold to overseas buyers.<ref name='unit'/><ref name="MfE">{{cite web | author=MfE | title = Which international units will be accepted for surrender in CP1? | work = Emissions trading bulletin No 11 | publisher = Ministry for the Environment (MfE), NZ Government | date = September 2009| url = http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-trading-bulletin-11/index.html#other | quote= A: There are no changes to the types of units that will be accepted into the NZ ETS (ie, CERs, ERUs and RMUs will be accepted) | accessdate = 18 August 2010}}</ref> However, temporary CERs and iCERS cannot be used in the NZ ETS, and neither can CERs and ERUs generated from nuclear projects.<ref>{{cite web |author=MfE |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate/emissions-factsheets/factsheet-27.html |title= Units of trade in the New Zealand emissions trading scheme |work= Factsheet 27 INFO 329 |publisher= Ministry for the Environment |accessdate= 15 July 2010 |date= October 2008}}</ref>
From 23 December 2011, [[Certified Emission Reduction]] units (CERs) from [[Fluoroform|HFC-23]] and [[Nitrous oxide]] (N<sub>2</sub>O) industrial gas destruction projects were banned from use in the NZ ETS, unless they had been purchased under future delivery contracts entered into prior to 23 December 2011. The use of CERs from the future delivery contracts ended in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/building/regulatory-updates/restricting-cers.html |title= Regulations restricting the use of HFC-23 and N2O CERs in the NZ ETS |author=MfE |date= 22 February 2012 |accessdate= 21 September 2012 |publisher=Ministry for the Environment}}</ref>

On September 2009, the Greenhouse Policy Coalition described the proposed changes to the NZ ETS as "a welcome move in the right direction". The Coalition stated that it approved of the half-cost unit surrender obligation in the first commitment period, the $12.50 price cap on carbon, and the slower phase-out of assistance to industry.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenhousepolicy.org.nz/Site/News_Releases/ETS_Changes_.aspx |title=ETS Changes Welcome |publisher=Greenhouse Policy Coalition |author=Catherine Beard |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=24 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113022755/http://greenhousepolicy.org.nz/Site/News_Releases/ETS_Changes_.aspx |archivedate=13 January 2015}}</ref>

The Business Council for Sustainable Development stated that New Zealand was risking "being left behind" in proposing an all-sectors, all-gases ETS that in 2015 would have almost no impact on heavy emitting industries facing international competition.<ref>{{cite web |first=Peter |last=Neilson |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU0909/S00792.htm |title=NZ needs to move to post-recession clean economy |publisher=Press Release: Business Council for Sustainable Development |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=1 October 2009}}</ref>
[[Federated Farmers]] commented that "there is no place for agricultural emissions in the ETS", that "the Government must seek to remove agriculture at Copenhagen in December",<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.fedfarm.org.nz/n1683.html |title=ETS announcement a mixed bag for agriculture |publisher= [[Federated Farmers]] of New Zealand |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=12 October 2009 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5kSkM1SnH |archivedate=12 October 2009}}</ref> and that the NZ ETS is "the road to economic hell being paved with good intentions".<ref name='hell'/>
===Editorial opinion=== ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'' described the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Bill as "backward legislation" and a "miserable offering to the international effort".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/carbon-trading/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501831&objectid=10609679 |title=Editorial: Another sorry chapter in emissions farce |newspaper= New Zealand Herald |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=3 February 2010 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5tgtkU5Yj |archivedate=23 October 2010}}</ref>

===Environmental organisations=== [[Greenpeace Aotearoa New Zealand]] noted that the intensity-based allocation of NZ Units to industry and the slow phase-out of free units would allow emissions to grow and described the NZ ETS as "pathetic".<ref name="greenpeace"/> Greenpeace's Simon Boxer described the NZETS to [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]] as "the worst emissions trading scheme in the world".<ref name='worst'>{{cite news|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Fonterra-vs-Greenpeace-The-debate-continues/tabid/572/articleID/130992/Default.aspx |title=Fonterra vs Greenpeace: The debate continues |quote=the worst emissions trading scheme in the world |work=(55 seconds); 3 News |author=Simon Boxer |publisher=TV3 |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=8 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929004136/http://www.3news.co.nz/Fonterra-vs-Greenpeace-The-debate-continues/tabid/572/articleID/130992/Default.aspx |archivedate=29 September 2012 }}</ref>
