===Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment=== In October 2009, New Zealand's independent environmental watchdog, Jan Wright, the [[Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment]], made a submission to the Select Committee considering National's amendments to the NZ ETS. The submission stated that the allocation of free units to industry was too generous and the length of the phase-out of free allocation was too slow. Without a carbon price signal to invest in low carbon technologies, emissions would continue to rise.<ref name="pce1"/>
In November 2009, Wright was sufficiently concerned that the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Amendment bill would result in increased emissions that she publicly urged politicians three times not to adopt the National Government's legislation. She opposed the removal of a firm cap on emissions, the reduction of price incentives to reduce emissions, and the heavy subsidies from taxpayers granted to emissions-intensive industry and agriculture by the intensity-based allocation of free units.<ref>{{cite press release |title=New bill 'weakens ETS' says Environment Commissioner |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0910/S00231.htm |publisher=Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment |date=15 October 2009 |accessdate=15 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |title= ETS amendments bill should not pass - Commissioner |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0911/S00146.htm |publisher=Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment |date=16 November 2009 |accessdate=16 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |title= ETS bill won't help environment - Commissioner |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO0911/S00277.htm |publisher=Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=25 November 2009}}</ref>
When the Climate Change Response (Moderated Emissions Trading) Act was adopted, Wright said in a radio interview "It's virtually certain our emissions will grow and the burden on the taxpayer will be uncurbed".<ref>{{cite news |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5tjvfduKe |archivedate=25 October 2010 |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-GreenBusiness/idUSTRE5AO0JB20091125?sp=true |title=New Zealand passes revamped carbon law |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=5 February 2010 |newspaper=Reuters |first=Gyles |last=Beckford}}</ref>
As the energy and liquid fossil fuels were about to enter the NZ ETS in July 2010, Wright expressed her concern that although the NZ ETS was the right framework, the subsidies to big emitters would limit the incentives to reduce emissions and impose significant costs on the taxpayer.<ref>{{cite press release |author= Jan Wright |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1006/S00482.htm |title= ETS Good but Emitter Subsidies Bad |publisher=Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment |date=30 June 2010 |accessdate=5 January 2011}}</ref>
==2012 review of the New Zealand ETS and amendments== The [[Climate Change Response Act 2002]] requires a review of the NZ ETS by an independent review panel every five years, with the first review to be completed in 2011. An ''Issues Statement and Call for Written Submissions'' document was released in March 2011, and the final report was released in September 2011. The review focused on the high-level design of the NZ ETS, particularly in the context of international efforts to tackle climate change post-2012.<ref name="ETSreview"/>
The report's major recommendations included: *phasing out the transitional two-for-one unit half-price surrender arrangement for a further three years to 2014, so that only from 2015 would emitters have to surrender one emissions unit for each tonne of emissions *a $5 per year increase in the price cap from 2013 (instead of no price cap) *that the agricultural sector should still enter in 2015, but should treated the same as other export industries *changes to the domestic ETS forestry accounting rules<ref>{{cite book |title=Doing New Zealand’s Fair Share. Emissions Trading Scheme Review 2011: Final Report |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/ets-review-2011/index.html |author=Emissions Trading Scheme Review Panel |year=2011 |publisher=Ministry for the Environment}}</ref>
An editorial in the NZ Herald said that there was no merit in the Government's view that lack of mitigation options meant that agriculture should be kept out of the NZ ETS. The editorial described this as 'extraordinary generosity' to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/carbon-trading/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501831&objectid=10752920 |title= Editorial: Farmers must share burden on emissions |publisher=The Herald |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
In April 2012, the Government released a consultation document in response to the review that stated that the Government intended to introduce amending legislation in July 2012, with the aim of passing it by the end of 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/consultation/ets/questions-answers.html#_Toc321912739 |title= Q7. What is the proposed process for updating the ETS in 2012? |date= 13 April 2012 |accessdate= 20 June 2012 |author=MfE |work= Questions and Answers: Updates to the NZ ETS in 2012 |publisher= Ministry for the Environment}}</ref> The ''National Business Review'' considered that in spite of the "fairly cryptic" nature of the Government's response to the review of the emissions trading scheme, it was likely that pastoral farming emissions would not enter the NZ ETS until 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/govt-adopts-uk-euro-tactics-emissions-trading-scheme-rh-p-116550 |title = Farming out of ETS until at least 2018 |first= Rob |last= Hosking |work = The National Business Review |date = 12 April 2012 |accessdate = 15 June 2012}}</ref>
In November 2012, the Government passed the Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading and Other Matters) Amendment Act 2012.<ref name='groser12'/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/bill/government/2012/0052/latest/DLM4676517.html |title=Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading and Other Matters) Amendment Act 2012 |year = 2012 |publisher= NZ Government}}</ref> The legislation extended the two-for-one unit surrender transitional measure indefinitely beyond 2012, indefinitely deferred the entry of agriculture, introduced an offsetting option for pre-1990 forests, created a statutory power to auction NZ units within an overall cap, and finally changed the treatment of the synthetic greenhouse gas sector.<ref name="2012 amend info"/> The Government stated that the amendments were necessary to: *"maintain the costs that the ETS places on the economy at current levels. This will ensure businesses and households do not face additional costs during the continued economic recovery; and that New Zealand continues to do its fair share on climate change." *"make a number of important changes designed to improve the operation of the ETS, providing more flexibility for forest landowners and ensuring the scheme is 'fit for purpose' after 2012."<ref name="2012 amend info" />
==2015 review of the ETS== In November 2015, the government started consultation on a review of the ETS.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mfe.govt.nz/consultation/new-zealand-ets-review-201516-consultation | title=Consultation for the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme review 2015/16 | publisher=Ministry for the Environment | accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref> Controversially, the question of whether to include agriculture in the scheme is not being considered in the review.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/290485/agriculture-left-out-of-emissions-review | title=Agriculture left out of emissions review | work=Radio New Zealand | date=25 November 2015 | accessdate=28 November 2015 | author=Bramwell, Chris}}</ref>
==Market performance and trading==
===Unit register=== On 6 December 2007, the New Zealand Emission Unit Register (NZEUR) was established. The NZEUR has the role of issuing, holding, transferring and retiring emission units in terms of the Kyoto Protocol. The initial use of the NZEUR was to record Kyoto emission units allocated to firms enrolled in the [[Ministry for the Environment (New Zealand)|Ministry for the Environment]]’s Projects to Reduce Emissions and Negotiated Greenhouse Agreements programmes, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry’s Permanent Forest Sink Initiative.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.beehive.govt.nz/node/31569 |title= Launch of register for Kyoto units |publisher=New Zealand Government |date= 6 December 2007 |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref>
===Market size=== At 31 December 2008, the NZ Emissions Unit Register (NZEUR) had 128 official account holders. All were foresters except for four energy companies. 45 of the foresters reported removals (sequestration) of 692,583 tonnes of CO2-e and 692,583 NZUs were issued into the market.<ref>{{cite web |title= Climate Change Response Act 2002 Section 89: Chief Executive Reporting |url= https://docs.google.com/open?id=0B8LhMBA3NXL4dHhCbEU3TkhaXzg |publisher = Ministry of Economic Development |date= 29 June 2009 |accessdate =17 August 2011 }}</ref> In the year to 31 December 2009, 97 mandatory NZETS participants and 380 voluntary participants (largely post-1990 foresters) were added as NZEUR account holders. Foresters reported removals (sequestration) of 4,460,095 tonnes of CO2-e. Some foresters surrendered 4,526 NZUs for emissions from deforestation. 4,460,095 NZUs were issued into the market.<ref>{{cite web |title= Climate Change Response Act 2002 Section 89: Chief Executive Reporting |url= http://www.epa.govt.nz/Publications/Section_89_CE_Reporting_2009.pdf |format=PDF |publisher = Ministry of Economic Development |date= 29 June 2010 |accessdate =17 August 2011 }}</ref> At 31 December 2010, there were 96 mandatory NZETS participants and 1,216 voluntary participants of which 1,195 were post-1990 foresters. Foresters reported removals (sequestration) of 9,445,606 tonnes of CO2-e. The quantity of emissions reported was 33,410,389 tonnes of CO2-e for the 2010 calendar year and 16,286,618 tonnes of CO2-e were reported for the NZETS compliance period from 1 July 2010 to 31 December 2010. Due to the two tonnes for one NZU arrangement, emitters surrendered 8,303,660 NZUs for their emissions. 12,776,026 NZUs were issued by free allocation into the market.<ref>{{cite web |title= Climate Change Response Act 2002 Section 89: Chief Executive of Ministry of Economic Development Reporting |url= http://www.epa.govt.nz/Publications/Section_89_CE_Reporting_2010.pdf |format=PDF |publisher = Ministry of Economic Development |date= 24 June 2011 |accessdate =17 August 2011 }}</ref> Forestry removals (sequestration) in the 2011 calendar year were 13,820,979 tonnes of CO2-e and the quantity of emissions reported was 31,803,198 tonnes of CO2-e. 11,596,460 NZUs were issued by free allocation into the market. Due to the two tonnes for one NZU arrangement, emitters surrendered 16,381,479 units for their emissions.<ref name='epa2012'>{{cite web |title= 2011 Report for the period 25 June 2011 to 20 June 2012, under section 89 and section 222E of the Climate Change Response Act 2002 |url= http://www.epa.govt.nz/Publications/Section_89_CE_Reporting2012.pdf |format=PDF |publisher = Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) |date= 21 June 2012 |accessdate =13 October 2012 }}</ref> At 21 June 2012, there were 286 mandatory NZETS participants and 2,264 voluntary participants of which 2,254 were post-1990 foresters.<ref name='epa2012'/>
===Export of units overseas=== In August 2009, forestry companies were selling units to NZ and international buyers. Forester Ernslaw One converted 520,000 NZ units into [[Assigned amount units]] and sold them to the Norwegian Government, in a landmark ground breaking deal brokered by leading New Zealand carbon broker, Carbon Market Solutions Ltd. At the time, it was the largest forestry carbon credit deal in the world. Industry sources estimated the prices were approximately $NZ21 to $NZ22 a tonne and that value of the trade would have been between $NZ10.9 million and $NZ11.4 million, depending on the exchange rate. Ernslaw One had also sold 50,000 units at $NZ20 (sales value about $NZ1 million worth) to a NZ buyer and then subsequently at the end of 2009 made a second 500,000 tonne trade with the Norwegian Government.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/73407/forests-carbon-credit-sale-world039s-biggest |title=Forests carbon credit sale world's biggest |first= Simon |last= Hartley |work= Otago Daily Times |date= 10 September 2009 |accessdate= 19 April 2012}}</ref>
===Import of international units=== As previously noted, the NZ ETS allows unlimited importing of international units which makes it a price-taker with only the international price as a constraint on emissions.<ref name='Moyes'/> In the first compliance period the six months to December 2010, less than 2 per cent of the surrendered units were imported from the international Kyoto markets (64 per cent had been bought from forest owners and 31 per cent had been allocated free to trade-exposed industrial emitters).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10742385 |title=Govt sends ETS report back for updating |first=Brian |last=Fallow |work=The Herald |date=2 August 2011 |accessdate=14 March 2014 }}</ref> In the 2011 calendar year, NZ emitters made a large switch from domestic NZUs to cheaper international units.<ref name='BD2012'/> Of the 16.3 million units surrendered, 11.7 million units (or 72%) were imported international units (being 4.2 million CERs 4.3 million ERUs and 3.2 million RMUs.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/building/reports/ets-report/ |title= NZ ETS 2011 Facts and figures |publisher = Ministry of Economic Development |date= August 2012 |accessdate= 13 October 2012}}</ref> In 2013, cheap international carbon credits made up 99.5 per cent of the units NZ emitters used to meet their obligations. Of these units, 91 percent were ERUs sourced from former Soviet Union countries that cannot be used in the European Union ETS.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11303894 |title=Clock is ticking for cheap credits |first =Brian |last=Fallow |date=5 August 2014 |accessdate=7 March 2015 |work=The NZ Herald }}</ref>
===Price movements=== [[File:Petrol-ets-2010-2015.svg|thumb|top|400px|New Zealand petrol prices and the NZETS component from 2010 to 2015]] Up to January 2011, market prices for NZ Units were largely set by the international price for [[Certified Emission Reduction]] (CER) units. In March 2011, European concerns over the implications of the [[Fukushima nuclear disaster]] for their nuclear reactors reduced atomic power generation and increased coal thermal generation. This caused extra demand for CERs in the [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme]] and CER prices exceeded $NZ25 a tonne, the effective price cap in the NZ ETS. NZ buyers switched from the more expensive CERS to cheaper NZUs which were traded at a record price of more than NZ$21 per tonne.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL3E7EI06H20110318?sp=true |title=New Zealand carbon price touches all-time high |author= Point Carbon/Reuters |publisher= Thomson Reuters |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=11 August 2011 |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/6BN7me9fi |archivedate= 13 October 2012 }}</ref> In July 2011, concerns over the Eurozone sovereign debt crisis combined with the high volumes of CERS being issued caused international CER prices to fall to a range between 9 and 10 euros. NZU prices fell to $NZ16.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU1107/S00881/the-anatomy-of-the-cer-price-melt-down.htm |title= The Anatomy of the CER Price Melt Down |publisher= Environmental Intermediaries And Trading Group Ltd |date= 28 July 2011 |access-date= 17 September 2016}}</ref>
By August 2012, the very low European carbon prices dragged the NZU price down to $NZ4.55 per tonne of carbon.<ref name='BD2012'>{{cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU1208/S00158/big-emitters-chasing-cheap-foreign-carbon-units-mfe-data.htm |title= Big emitters chasing cheap foreign carbon units: MfE data |author= BusinessDesk |work= Scoop News |date= 3 August 2012 |accessdate= 13 October 2012}}</ref> In mid September 2012, NZUs were selling for $NZ4.20 a tonne.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.odt.co.nz/news/business/226151/fears-emissions-trading-scheme |title=Fears for emissions trading scheme |first= Simon |last= Hartley |work= The Otago Daily Times |date= 17 September 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> In late October 2012, New Zealand carbon prices dropped to about $NZ1 a tonne for some types of credits.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/politics/7873918/New-Zealand-may-quit-Kyoto |title=New Zealand May Quit Kyoto Protocol |author1=Rob Stock |author2=Neil Reid |lastauthoramp=yes |work=The Dominion Post |date= 28 October 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> On 10 December 2012, the NZU spot price was $2.70 and it had declined by 72 percent over the 2012 year.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-12-10/new-zealand-has-kyoto-carbon-access-until-2015-government-says.html |title=New Zealand Has Kyoto Carbon Access Until 2015, Government Says |first=Chris |last=Bourke |work=Bloomberg |date= 10 December 2012 |accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref> In February 2013, Westpac's carbon dealing desk noted that imported European carbon credits were trading for 28 NZ cents and the price for NZUs was $NZ2.50.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/8252659/Carbon-credit-price-meltdown |title=Carbon credit price meltdown |first=Rob |last=Stock |date=3 February 2013 |accessdate= 7 February 2015|work=Sunday Star Times }}</ref> In January 2014 the price of one NZU was about NZ$3.50, up from NZ$2 a year earlier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2014/05/19572833/state-trends-carbon-pricing-2014 |title=State and trends of carbon pricing 2014 |author1=World Bank |author2=Ecofys. |year=2014 |publisher=World Bank Group }}</ref>
==Impacts on prices==
===Petrol=== In September 2007, the 2008 NZETS was expected to increase the GST-inclusive retail price of petrol by 3.7 cents a litre (2.5%) under a $15 carbon price scenario and 6.1 cents (4%) under a $25 scenario.<ref name='FETS7'>{{cite book |author= MfE |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/climate-change/framework-new-zealand-emissions-trading-scheme/7-impacts-emissions |title=The Framework for a New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme - 7 The Impacts of the Emissions Trading Scheme |chapter= 7.2.1 Emissions from electricity |publisher=Ministry for the Environment |accessdate=18 March 2015 |date=September 2007 |series=Ref. ME810 }}</ref> The Labour Government predicted that the NZETS may cause petrol prices to rise by about 4 cents a litre.<ref name='QA'>{{cite press release |title=New Zealand emissions trading scheme Questions and answers |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0709/S00350.htm |date= 20 September 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2015 |publisher= New Zealand Government |quote="We expect fuel prices may increase by about 4 cents a litre."}}</ref>
Between 1 July 2010 and February 2015, the estimated NZETS component of the retail petrol price has ranged from a maximum of 2.4 cents per litre from late 2010 to June 2011 to a minimum of half a cent from July 2013 to December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.med.govt.nz/sectors-industries/energy/liquid-fuel-market/weekly-oil-price-monitoring/weekly-table.csv |title= Weekly oil price monitoring - Data used to produce weekly graph |publisher=Ministry of Business Innovation & Employment |date= 10 March 2015 |accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
===Electricity=== In 2007, the 2008 NZETS was expected to increase the retail price of electricity by 1 cent/kwh (5%) under a $15 carbon price scenario and 2 cents/kwh (10%) under a $25 scenario.<ref name='FETS7'/> The official "NZETS Question and Answers" fact sheet of September 2007 noted that the NZETS may cause retail electricity bills to increase by 4 or 5%.<ref name='QA'/> In 2009 the 2009 NZETS was expected to increase electricity prices by 5% (1c/kWh) in comparison with an increase of by 10% (2c/kWh) under the 2008 NZETS.<ref name="faq"/> In April 2011, a report prepared by consultants Covec for the Ministry for the Environment concluded that the NZETS had no discernible impact on either wholesale or retail electricity prices.<ref name='Denne'>{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechange.govt.nz/emissions-trading-scheme/ets-review-2011/supporting-info/impacts-of-actual-vs-expected-effects.pdf |title=Impacts of the NZETS: Actual vs Expected Effects |first= Tim |last= Denne |publisher=Covec Ltd |date=April 2011 }}</ref> In October 2012, the five major electricity generating companies were asked by officials about NZETS costs being passed through in electricity prices. The companies advised that there was no distinguishable or visible impact of the NZETS on wholesale electricity prices.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/50SCFE_ADV_00DBHOH_BILL11566_1_A281916/d3acb3335ae1785ee251d624b6b1ed89753f0430 |title=Advice to the Finance and Expenditure Select Committee on the Climate Change Response (Emissions Trading and Other Matters) Amendment Bill -Responses to information requests from the select committee meeting on 26 September 2012 |chapter=Request 49: Impact of carbon costs on electricity prices p 11 |publisher= Prepared by the Ministry for the Environment and the Ministry for Primary Industries |date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref>
